tn.text: "So it happened." This phrase is used to introduce the next event in the storyline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
a strong wind that spins around and around

tn.ref: As Yahweh lives, and as you live
tn.text: "As surely as Yahweh lives and as you live." Here Elisha compares the certainty that Yahweh and Elijah are alive to the certainty of what he is saying. This is a way of making a solemn promise. AT: "I solemnly promise you that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. AT: "A group of men who were prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: As Yahweh lives, and as you live, I will not leave you
tn.text: "As surely as Yahweh lives and as you live, I will not leave you." Here Elisha compares the certainty that Yahweh and Elijah are alive to the certainty of what he is saying. This is a way of making a solemn promise. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:01|2:2]]. AT: "I solemnly promise you that I will not leave you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Then the sons of the prophets who were at Jericho came to Elisha and said to him
tn.text: "When Elijah and Elisha came near Jericho, the sons of the prophets who were from there said to Elisha"

This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of men who were prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: As Yahweh lives, and as you live, I will not leave you
tn.text: "As surely as Yahweh lives and as you live, I will not leave you." Here Elisha compares the certainty that Yahweh and Elijah are alive to the certainty of what he is saying. This is a way of making a solemn promise. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:01|2:2]]. AT: "I solemnly promise you that I will not leave you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"50 of the sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of men who were prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that they were standing, facing them. AT: "stood facing them" or "stood watching them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
outer piece of clothing used as a covering

tn.ref: The river divided on both sides so that the two of them walked over on dry ground
tn.text: "The water of the Jordan River opened up so there was a dry path for Elijah and Elisha to cross over to the other side"
"to the right and the left." This refers to the right and the left of where Elijah struck the water.
"it happened"
This refers to crossing the Jordan River. AT: "crossed over the Jordan River" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: before I am taken from you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "before Yahweh takes me from you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a double portion of your spirit
tn.text: Here Elijah's spirit refers to his spiritual power. AT: "twice as much of your spiritual power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: a chariot of fire and horses of fire
tn.text: Here the phrase "of fire" means that these were surround by fire. AT: "a chariot surrounded by fire pulled by horses surrounded by fire" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_possession]])

tn.ref: went up by a whirlwind into heaven
tn.text: "was carried into the sky by a whirlwind." Translate the word "whirlwind" the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:01|2:1]].
Elisha is calling Elijah his respected leader.
People would often tear their clothes as a sign of great sadness or grief. AT: "ripped them in two pieces to show his great sadness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
The cloak was the otter clothing of a prophet. It was the sign of his job. When Elisha took Elijah's cloak he was saying he was taking Elijah's place as prophet.

tn.ref: Where is Yahweh, the God of Elijah?
tn.text: Elisha is asking if Yahweh is with him as he was with Elijah. AT: "Yahweh, the God of Elijah, are you here with me?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: they divided on both sides and Elisha crossed over
tn.text: The river separated and Elisha walked to the other side on dry ground, the same way he did previously when he was with Elijah.
"to the right and the left." This refers to the right and the left of where Elijah struck the water.

This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: bowed themselves to the ground before him
tn.text: They are showing him deep respect and acknowledging him as their new leader.

tn.ref: The spirit of Elijah does rest on Elisha
tn.text: Here Elijah's "spirit" refers to his spiritual power. This speaks of Elisha having this spiritual power as if it were something that physically rested upon him. AT: "Elisha does have the same spiritual power that Elijah did" or "The spiritual power Elijah had is now with Elisha" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: See now, among your servants there are fifty strong men. Let them go
tn.text: These men are referring to themselves when they say "fifty strong men." AT: "See now, we are fifty strong men and we are now your servants. Let us go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"50 strong men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: But when they urged Elisha until he was ashamed
tn.text: The sons of the prophets kept asking Elisha until he felt bad about saying "no." AT: "They kept asking Elisha until he felt bad for denying their request, so" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Did I not say to you, 'Do not go'?
tn.text: Elisha uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that he had told them previously what would happen. This can be written as a statement. AT: "I told you that you should not go, because you would not find him!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"The leaders of the city"

tn.ref: the situation of this city is pleasant
tn.text: This means that the city is located in a good place. AT: "this city is in a good place" or "this city is in a good location" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The men refer to Elisha here as "my master" to honor him.
"producing good crops"
This speaks of Yahweh making the bad water pure as if he healed it. AT: "made the waters pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: there will be no more death or unfruitful land
tn.text: This refers to things caused by the bad water. This also can be written in positive form. AT: "there will be no more death or problems with crops caused by this water" or "from now on this water will bring life and help the land become fruitful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the waters have remained pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that something remains in a certain condition until the present time. AT: "by the word which Elisha spoke, and have always remained pure since" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: went up from there to Bethel
tn.text: The phrase "went up" is used her because Bethel is higher in elevation than Jericho.
The young boys wanted Elisha to go away from them and expressed this by saying "go up." AT: "Go away" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
A bald person does not have any hair on their head. The young boys were mocking Elisha for having a bald head.
two of the boys** - "42 of the boys" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
